review:
This was the third and final installment of the Time Mysteries series, and I must say, it was a truly well-crafted tale of the time. While storyline-wise, I would still prefer the second game over this final installment, it would be unwise to say this game was a let down. 

Achievements were not difficult to get. The first half of the game is also similar to the second game, yet the second half is where things get immediately interesting. This game ties up the first game, and you will notice the big upgrade of the areas similarly shown from the first game. In essence, this happened to be what fascinated me into liking this game as much as the second installment.

One thing that only bothered me was the inability to lock the inventory to see it all the time. Anything else, such as voice acting, storytelling, puzzles, or characters, I have no other comments about.

I have strictly played this game for about 2 hours (basis on first and last achievement taken, one-sitting playthrough), do not believe the progress Steam shows you as I write this review. On average, that is a good length of gameplay. While I did mention preference-wise that I preferred the second game, I would definitely still rate this game an [u]8/10[/u] as a closing chapter for the series. A positive recommend guaranteed.

review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

review:
An average hidden object game that is fully voice acted and animated.

Compared to the previous entries, there are improvements, but it still does not reach the desired quality.

Graphics are still too dated. In most hidden object scenes it is quite challenging to recognize items due to the blurriness and shadowing.

The game has animated cutscenes but their quality is average.

Sounds, background music, and voice acting are good.

The game is the easiest one of the series. The map is still essential for finding freshly activated hidden object scenes that are popping up seemingly randomly at already visited locations.

The story is a direct continuation of the previous entries and serves as a final conclusion.

The best feature of the series, the future changing aspect is underutilized.

There are no collectables.

There is a bonus story which is surprisingly only a mixture of scenes from the previous and the current game.

review:
[u]Recommendation[/u]: It's a mildly fun Artifex Mundi hidden object game, with all the typical elements: crows, the supernatural, the same voice actors, creepy deepfake animation, and tokens, token, tokens!

[u]Critique[/u]: For the achievements (and because I play so many of these games lately), I always play these on Expert mode, so I can't speak to how the game is on lower difficulties. But you get the same types of puzzles in this game as many others: random items found in hidden object scenes are needed to unlock doors so you can progress through a story. Sometimes the completely random objects are acquired through other types of puzzles, like a pipes puzzle, or variations of on/off puzzles (where you toggle one item, and it toggles all the adjacent items). This game is novel in that it includes an arcade game at one point: the classic game of Snake, which felt fresh and unique after so many games using the exact same puzzles over and over again.

This game also downplays the supernatural a bit, playing up the science fiction elements of a Kyle Reese-like freedom fighter traveling back in time from a post-apocalyptic future to look for help. The supernatural is still there, of course, because this has been shoehorned into the narrative of the previous game in which the descendants of the wizard Merlin combat the evil witch Viviana. At least in this game, her name is consistently spelled "Viviana," unlike Time Mysteries 2.
It also contains a fun twist at the end. At this point, I should EXPECT these sorts of twists, but I actually still enjoy them.

In general, I feel like this game wasn't as good as the second game. Some of the games feel more linear than others, and this one felt particularly linear to me. But I [b]really[/b] appreciate that this game did not have an alternative game to the hidden object scenes that you [i]have[/i] to complete to get all the achievements.

[u]Review[/u]: Esther (sometimes mispelled as "Ester") continues her adventures after the second game. [spoiler]But she is no longer a governess in the 19th century; having claimed her birthright, she's now a seasoned time traveler comfortably flitting between centuries. But a traveler from the far future appears and reveals that Viviana is still causing mischief....and that, unless she is stopped, she will turn the world into a radioactive wasteland straight out of the Fallout games. So the first part of the game has you traveling back in time to meet Merlin's daughter, Nimue, and get her help in figuring out where the solution from the second game went wrong. It turns out that Viviana was herself corrupted by another time traveler from the future, a man who went mad in grief and rage and just wanted to see the world burn. So rather than stop Viviana - which you did in the second game - you are trying to stop Viviana from getting corrupted. That means finding out about the future and figuring out what went wrong that caused the apocalypse. Then, when you figure out how it happened, you have to figure out how to prevent the madman from destroying the world.

In the end, the madman isn't evil, just grief-stricken. You prevent the accident that caused the engineer from the future to give up on trying to solve the climate crisis, and then his partner survives, and together they create the device that cleans the air of the planet.[/spoiler]

review:
Última entrega de la saga, continuista conlas dos anteriores para lo bueno y para lo malo. Continúa el desarrollo de la trama, dándole por fin cierre. Sin embargo, los problemas que ya aparecían en las anteriores entregas, siguen estando presentes. Si bien se agradece que en esta entrega haya un mayor equilibrio entre escenas de objetos ocultos y puzzles, éstos últimos siguen siendo demasiado fáciles y típicos. Aquí, la innovación del viaje entre el presente y el futuro se usa mucho menos y con menos "efecto" en los puzzles...siendo además algo tedioso tanta "animación" al viajar (ya sabemos que estamos viajando, hace falta todo el rato el relojito¿?).

Las animaciones y gráficos siguen siendo bastante deficientes y lo único que mejora algo es la música que crea algo de ambiente.

En definitiva, como en los otros, si eres un gran fan y lo consigues rebajado, tal vez te interese...pero yo diría que casi seguro que te lo puedes ahorrar.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042771493', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 404, 'last_played': 1682234843}
review:
And here we are with the final installment of the series.

This game goes back and tries to knit the story of the first 2 games together as a full arc. The second game didn't seem to have any connection to the first one except that the same "Ambrose" family name is used, but I didn't think they'd be making all of it into a trilogy.

The game has some callbacks to the first 2 and borrows elements from both of them, which I liked. It's very much a "greatest hits" of the previous games. The hidden object puzzles in this game were better, and there were no puzzles that were presented in a way that didn't at least explain what you should be doing, so that was nice as well, I'm glad that's better in this game. This game has a bonus adventure, which is always welcome.

There were still issues though, much as I'd like to say this one is "fixed." The biggest and most frustrating thing for me was the item bar in the HUD. In many hidden object games, it always displays, but you may have the option to hide it until you mouse over it to select an item. The games that do decide to auto-hide the item bar all usually include an option in the settings to always show it, and even go the extra mile of having a "lock" button to keep it open without having the go into the game settings at all. This game not only hides the item bar, but there's no option at all I could fine in the HUD or in the game settings to show it permanently. If there is some setting for this I missed somewhere, it's very poorly implemented if users can't find it. I play on a touchscreen, so having to use the trackpad to keep going back to open the item menu was very frustrating and it significantly impacted my enjoyment of the game.

That aside, the story does "conclude," but it still really never touches on the ending of 2 directly, and the callbacks to the other games, while nice, don't feel like a good, cohesive story that was all planned out, but more like the game devs wanted to include them and then just fit them in where they could.

The bonus adventure was even a little strange, because it essentially is just more of the ending of the game. It's from a different person's perspective, but could probably just have been part of a longer base game. Sometimes these bonus adventures add some plot to set up the sequel, but since this was the final game in the series, it's odd to finish the game's ending in a separate adventure like this. The events of the bonus adventure are also kind of strange, like the ending changes X, and this allows someone else in the past to change Y. But at the end the main characters of the base game tells us this is going to happen, so just a very strange implementation of the bonus adventure.

Overall, I still say there are better series than this one. If you've played everything else, it certainly has more puzzles and it's not terrible, but if you only have enough to spend on 1 series and you're trying to decide, I think you'd be happier choosing something else.

review:
З цією серією якісь гойдалки – погано / добре. Нажаль третя частина не виглядає гарною. Сюжет із подорожуванням у часі можна було б скласти цікавіше. Те що є ну зовсім без інтриги, а приплетені сюди персони і рішення не вписуються (або читаються гравцем як безглузді). Та це ще не все – із оригінальністю головоломок теж проблема, ніби стандартне повторювання та оформлення, цікавих знахідок майже не має. Після-смак як у газети, котру читаєш у автобусі і швидко забуваєш.
Єдине що смакує – це перевірений рушій на котрому побудовано гру. Приємна графіка, звук, набридлива музична тема. Система додасть приємні напрацювання, котрі допомагають гравцеві не застрягнути у грі: мапу з підказками, візуальний контур об’єктів для пошуку, альтернативна грі з пошуку предметів, щоденник із записами, додаткова глава. Ще є куди шліфувати, оскільки я примудрився застрягнути і підказки не допомагали.
Якщо ви чекаєте детектив / фентезі / подорожі у часі – воно є, але подано у дірявому стакані. У студії є більш вишукані ігри, на котрі краще звернути увагу.

review:
Time Mysteries 3: The Final Enigma é o final épico da série de aventuras de viagem no tempo. Diante do cataclismo mágico iminente, Ester Ambrose tem que lutar para salvar seu futuro mais uma vez.

Destruir a tumba de cristal de Viviana deveria transformar a luta de Ester Ambrose contra os poderes do mal em nada mais do que um eco distante de seu passado, uma fraca lembrança de um pesadelo que nunca mais aconteceria com ela.

No entanto, a parte mais difícil e perigosa, mas também a mais fascinante da história ainda está para começar para a herdeira da família Ambrose. Para salvar o futuro, ela precisa enfrentar o passado em outra jornada no tempo e no espaço.

review: I'm not really sure why this game has very positive reviews. 3/4 of the way in (maybe sooner?), it starts to become a serious slog and more than one of the Hidden object Puzzles become incredibly cheap with one or two of the items in them to locate. The inventory bar is slow to update when you click the left an right arrows (once you have more items than can be displayed) In my opinion, the story is meh as well. And the artwork... Ugh. A good HoG has beautiful vibrant colors of fantastical worlds. This game's art, while isn't bad from an artist skill level, but it certainly doesn't captivate at all! This adds to the overall "slog" feeling. If the game was vibrant with beautiful fantastical worlds, renavigating the same locations over and over again trying to figure out what to do wouldn't be so bad. But you're stuck with traversing the same dull boring lifeless locations. I think I'm near the end, and much of the time I'm finding myself just mashing the left-click button just to get the damn game over with, this tells me how I actually feel about the game when trying to figure out whether my experience is positive or negative.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971284198', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1657169688}
review:
Well, how should I put it....

My review on Time Mysteries 2 was quite harsh... and I stand by it. Personal opinion and view of course.
Time Mysteries 3 is.... I guess the conclusion to this series? Since it's Final and all.

It's overall better than the last entry. I think things flow better, the number of active scenes at a time gets limited a bit, and I also noticed at least part of the hidden object parts that gets revealed overtime are... sometimes closer to the last action you did.

But for the most part it's still the same as the last entry. It's super linear, meaning you need to do something to unlock the next part. The hidden object parts are still messy. There are some very irritating puzzles, although less than in the previous entry. At some point in the game the hidden object parts go back to being randomly placed, meaning you need to go hunt what activated this time. And the whole thing is kinda arbitrary... like multi part keys, objects and whatnot you need to find to proceed.
Remains the problem of having a bunch of visible stuff to solve, but a linear path to do, so you can't stick to searching for a solution of one of the things alone.

Example, there is a part in distant future where you have a room with a cabinet/wardrobe that can visibly be opened with a gas mask token.
The token itself is visible inside an abandoned car just outside the building, so it should be a matter of breaking it open and taking it, right?
Nope. You have to make a whole way around doing a whole ton of stuff beforehand until you find a hook and line to get the car to unlock, then you get it. This is in the bonus round.
But there are several more stuff that kinda goes like this.

So... in comparison to more modern, better done Artifex Mundi titles... this one is pretty bad. It more or less compares to the earlier titles, only far overly complicated and hard. That might be something some people want, but it's the frustrating kinda hard, so just be aware.

But to be very fair... it's still an Artifex Mundi title, and so in comparison to hidden object games of other publishers and devs... it's just miles ahead.
That's the thing. I have played perhaps a couple of hidden object games from other publishers that were comparable to Artifex Mundi, but at least half a dozen or more that are way worse than even this Time Mysteries entire series, like several times worse than the worst Artifex Mundi title.

So, being a bit less frustrating to me in comparison to the previous entry in this series... I have to recommend. Had to use a hint once because of one very poorly explained puzzle, and even with the hint the solution was still kind of a guess.

Story wise, I think it's on part with most Artifex Mundi games. It's a bit corny and rushed, but still kinda interesting.
You basically have to save your lineage, your ancestor being Merlin, which is why you have the time traveling device and powers. Merlin was betrayed by his... wife? Partner? Which gave rise to the whole story, but actually, a twist there because the root source of all evil lies elsewhere... you know how it goes.

The Bonus round makes a lot of use of scenes from Time Mysteries 2, despite being an epilogue to this game.
There you go then, one more Artifex Mundi series finished. o/

review:
时间之谜系列第三作，比第二作要好了很多，特别是前半部分，设计到的谜题和需要找东西时，都是在附近亮起寻物谜题，解谜流畅度还是可以的，只不过到了后半部分，又变得特别拉胯了，缺个东西，寻物谜题在几个世纪远的地方亮起，要知道这可是全地图无限制的啊，你隔着老远亮着这么个寻物谜题，真是是又得重新找半天，就好像设定一样一个寻物谜题就只能亮两次也必须亮两次是吧，真是无语了。不过故事比第二作要好多了，但还是摆脱不了拉胯的成分，玩着玩着就想打瞌睡了。寻物谜题的重复利用率非常的高，特别是DLC里的寻物谜题，不仅重复利用了第二作的寻物谜题，连第三作主线的寻物谜题都重复利用了，真是敷衍的离谱。

虽然感觉上是比第二作好了那么点，但仍然拿不起高分，只能和二作一样，给个6/10分，勉强及格吧。

author: {'steamid': '76561197970310850', 'num_games_owned': 335, 'num_reviews': 257, 'playtime_forever': 523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 523, 'last_played': 1641757755}
review:
[b]7/10[/b]

[h1]Ich habe mit der Trilogie meinen Frieden geschlossen[/h1]

Nachdem ich beiden Vorgängern den Daumen runter geben musste, wollte ich Teil 3 nun endlich mögen. Mit ein paar zugedrückten Augen ist mir das gelungen ^^
Kurzfassungen...
Kritik an Teil 1: holprige, undetaillierte Story, nervige Mittelaltermusik, Wimmelbilder schlecht aufgelöst und unfair
Kritik an Teil 2: das immer gleiche musikalische Hauptthema, ein sehr volles Inventar, aber v.a. mühsames Hin- und Hergereise durch die Zeit

Teil 3 ist nun im Grunde aufgebaut wie Teil 2, hat zwar auch dessen Macken mitgenommen, aber ich habe mich damit arrangiert und gelernt, damit umzugehen.

Erstmal zu den positiven Dingen:
Die Story ist in Ordnung, es kommen eine Menge Figuren zusammen.
Viele faire Wimmelbilder, zum Ende hin (wie in anderen WBS tatsächlich auch schon erlebt) einfach, teils gar zu einfach.
Die Minispiele gehen gut von der Hand, viele sind mittel, einige zu einfach und manche auch eine ganz schöne Ackerei. Je nach Geschmack vermutlich.

Steigerung zum zweiten Teil:
Das musikalische Thema wird je nach Ort und Zeit variiert, was mir gefallen hat. Denn ich mag es grundsätzlich sehr.
Die Benutzung des Inventars gibt einen sehr viel besseren Flow her. Man sammelt nicht mehr so viel Zeug und kann auch fast durchgehend assoziieren, wofür das alles gebraucht wird.
Es gibt nun insgesamt drei Orte (mit je zwei Zeiten), also mehr Abwechslung - und endlich auch die Zukunft. Im letzten Abschnitt des Spiels wechselt es nochmal woanders hin. Zwar so gesehen auch an keinen brandneuen Ort (von Teil 1 bekannt), aber zumindest kommt Abwechslung rein.

Weiter bestehendes Manko:
Die vielen Orte und ständigen Zeitreisen im späteren Verlauf, um irgendwo das nächste Wimmelbild zu finden - bzw. ein fehlender mittlerer Schwierigkeitsgrad, der einen die Wimmelbilder finden lässt, einen aber sonst nicht wie auf Schienen durchs Spiel führt. Die Tippfunktion funktioniert nach wie vor nicht zuverlässig und führt einen nicht sicher zum aktuellen Ziel.
Lösung:
Ich habe gelernt, mir die Orte einzuprägen, an denen es Wimmelbilder gibt, um sie bei Bedarf wieder aufzusuchen. So irrt man nicht sinnlos in der Gegend rum und verschwendet Zeit. In Teil 3 kann man sich aufgrund der Klarheit des Inventars zumindest oft sicher sein, wann wirklich nichts Anderes mehr geht als wimmeln, und so gezielt nach diesem nächsten Schritt suchen.

Die üblichen mangelhaften Übersetzungen in den Wimmelbildern möchte man schon gar nicht mehr erwähnen. Das meiste ist ok, aber manches kann man gar nicht glauben...

Das Bonusabenteuer ist hier, wie in anderen Reviews zu lesen, wirklich nicht so pralle. Sehr kurz, inhaltlich nicht wirklich bereichernd (schon deutlich besser erlebt sowas) und mit recycelten Wimmelbildern aus Teil 2 und 3.
Trotzdem hat's Spaß gemacht, weil es gut durchging. Ein paar schöne Minispiele waren allemal dabei.
Positiv überraschend ist, dass sie nur für das Bonuskapitel den Zeitreiseapparat (Karte/Schnellreise) nochmal neu designt haben.

Insgesamt:

[h1]Rechtfertigt die Trilogie nicht, ist aber zumindest der beste Teil der Serie[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561199036503764', 'num_games_owned': 590, 'num_reviews': 378, 'playtime_forever': 142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 142, 'last_played': 1639846163}
review:
Путешествия во времени вечно создают много вопросов с точки зрения логичности происходящего, но сценаристов из [url=https://store.steampowered.com/publisher/artifexmundi]Artifex Mundi[/url] это не испугало, поэтому [url=https://store.steampowered.com/bundle/2582/Time_Mysteries_Collection/]серия[/url] продолжилась. И если обычно я утверждал, что на сюжет в играх такого жанра я не обращаю внимание, то в данном случае, простите, не могу сдержаться.

[b]Time Mysteries 3[/b] классический квест с поиском предметов, задачки в котором увлекают своим количеством и простотой. Нарисовано всё приятно и красочно. Разработчики даже вернули функцию "радар", которую я упоминал в отзыве о [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/zhareg/recommended/313650/]прошлой части[/url]. То есть ничто не предвещало беды.

Но раз уж это трилогия, то пришлось как-то объединить стилистику первых двух игр, которые, честно говоря, были довольно разными. Да, рассказ вёлся об одном семействе, но даже путешествия во времени осуществлялись в оригинале и в сиквеле не одинаково. Можно было бы не запариваться, сделать очередного злодея в другом наборе эпох, но увы и ах. Вероятно, авторы отнеслись к этой истории слишком серьёзно, что заметно хотя бы по наличию дополнительных глав в [b]Time Mysteries 2[/b] и [b]Time Mysteries 3[/b]. Но стремление связать всё в единую эпопею сделало из истории какую-то непонятную кашу. Особенно меня рассмешило то, что решением глобальных бед для множества поколений прошлого и будущего оказались [spoiler]чертежи очистителя воздуха[/spoiler].

Игра абсолютно нормальная для своего жанра. Просто рука не поднимается ставить палец вверх за такой сюжет. Хотя я не требовал многого!

author: {'steamid': '76561198106507444', 'num_games_owned': 339, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 493, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1625878161}
review:
This game is really terrible. How many of the same puzzles can they pack into one game? Seems like this game is basically just HO puzzles and press buttons in a certain order to open a secret door. Incredibly lazy writing and incredibly boring game. I skipped a bunch of the puzzles because there was absolutely no skill involved and I didn't care enough to try to figure out which order to press buttons in. 

And once again they decided to take away the map in the last half of the game for no apparent reason. Part of playing on "casual" level is not having to click from place to place to figure out what needs done where. I wouldn't be surprised if I learned this was designed by some new guy at the company who was trying out different formats. It really was riddle with horrible decisions.

Artifex is usually great at these kinds of games, but this seems like a bargain basement version of the quality games we expect from them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198154273655', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 194, 'last_played': 1615243352}
review:
I hate to not recommend an Artifex Mundi P&C game, because I absolutely love these type of games - and especially the creators. But this one in particular ... OK, so let me start with: I played through the first two games in this series, the Time Mysteries, and I was pleasantly surprised that I enjoyed the first two. The second one was interesting because of the continuation of the storyline from the first. But the gameplay is kind of clunky and I worry about every HOP I see because the different items will have the same name in different HOPs and you never really know wtf to look for... This game, the third in the series, made me MAD. I was angry when playing this, but due to my mere "OCD" about finishing a series and getting 100% achievements made me play through it all. 
I guess if you are interested in the whole story it IS a good story, it's captivating and fun, but the gameplay, setup and voice acting is not very good, and there are so many annoying traits in this game, like the time-hops where you have to wait to go places and urgh... Yeah, I'm glad it's over now. 

However, as I leave this game on "not recommended" I guess if you're like me and want to play through Artifex Mundi games because the developers are just that good, keep in mind that this is an old game, a bad one because it's old, so it can be forgiven for that. I got this on sale so I don't regret anything, but I would unfortunately not recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044715770', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 268, 'last_played': 1603327191}
review:
Not a great game. Far, far, far from AM's best, but worth buying on deep sale.

Main game has a lot of hidden object scenes, but many are reused, and a few objects are barely visible, mostly obscured or just badly drawn. 

Mini puzzles are OK, nothing special. 

Plot is scattershot and involves a LOT of jumping around in time, and from scene to scene--go to one room, get one single object, jump to a different time and room, use the object, get next object in the chain, repeat over and over. Protagonist suffers from major put-it-down-itis, constantly needs another screwdriver or hammer or thin knife; her life would be far less complicated if she'd just hang onto the first tools she gets.

Most of the HO scenes just appear for no good reason, you need to get the next object in a chain, poof, there's an HO scene to get it from. 

Music is OK, but there's this regular thumping noise that is headache-inducing. 

Bonus game also has several HO scenes, but some of them are exactly the same ones--down to finding the same objects--as in the main game. There are a few bugs in the bonus game, no show stoppers, just clunky interface stuff.

Overall, meh. It scratches the HO and mini-puzzle itch.

review:
Mit Time Mysteries: The Final Enigma endet die Zeitreise-Trilogie und schließt damit die Geschichte rund um die Familie Ambrose ab. 

Zwar macht der dritte Teil vieles besser, als seine beiden Vorgänger, komplett überzeugen kann er aber dennoch auch nicht. Die Wimmelbilder sind nun sehr einfach gehalten. Die wenigen Mini-Spiele sind soweit ganz okay. Aber auch in diesem Teil verkommt das Zeitreisethema im Verlauf des Spiels immer mehr zu einem stupiden Hin- und Herreisen. Wirklich schade! Das Bonuskapitel hätte man sich sparen können, einfach nur komplett recycelte Wimmelbilder.

Da wie schon bei den Vorgängern die erste Hälfte des Spiels eigentlich ganz spaßig ist, bevor es zu sehr in willkürliches Hin- und Herhüpfen zwischen den Zeiten verkommt, gibt es mangels der Möglichkeit einer neutralen Bewertung einen Daumen hoch.

review:

The reason I don't recommend the third instalment is because it reuses so many assets and minigames from the first two games, especially during the latter half of the game. It feels a bit lazy and rushed. Of course they take place in the same universe/story, but that didn't stop them from having variety up until that point. There's even two hidden object scenes that are almost completely recycled.

It was nice to see the story concluded but I didn't feel like this was up to par with the previous two games in the series.

review:
Perhaps Artifex Mundis worst HOG, least of the many I've played.

It's very short, which to me isn't a probem in itself but definetly not worth full prize. It's art style is generally ugly and/or rather boring. The voice acting is awful. Story nonsensical, even for HOG's standard. Puzzles very easy, apart from technically flawed ones, like ones where colors represent value and the colors are hard to tell apart and scenes in which you are asked to find, say, a pen and they make a difference between a pen and a marker, which looks like two pens honestly. Same with being asked to find a, I don't know, a spoon perhaps, and you swear you can see several spoons but none of them seems to be the one you're asked to find, or when objects just stick up a tiny part so you can't make out what they are, but you manage by just blindly click all over. You get kinda frustrated at that type of design choices. Also, the achievements are bugged. You will not get the "Got all other achievements" one even when you do, perhaps because of getting them in a second playthrough. It's a pain for 100%-ers.

Artifex Mundi is usually THE best for HOG and HOP, but avoid this one. I don't know if the previous entries in the series are as bad, but I imagine so. I really don't mind silly stories, repetetive puzzles and short gameplay, but I do NEED nice art style, good or at least decent voice acting and music, and functional puzzles and gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034928324', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 172, 'playtime_forever': 156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1584483392}
review:
Realizzato in maniera grezza e superficiale, questo nuovo capitolo della serie di giochi "Trova L'oggetto" della artifex mundi non colpisce nel segno, in nessun ambito.
Immaginando di non aver giocato altri titoli della stessa casa sviluppatrice si può solo constatare che il tutto è stato realizzato grezzamente dalla trama agli enigmi.
Ci si trova infatti di fronte a enigmi fin troppo semplici, senza alcuna curva di difficoltà, facendo scorrere il gioco verso le circa 3 ore nelle quali passeremo gran parte del tempo a saltellare da una zona all'altra.
La trama è a tratti imbarazzante, sembra di leggere un libro per bambini a cui mancano delle pagine e che improvvisamente nel finale, chiuso in fretta e furia, sembra abbiano finito il tempo e i soldi per portare a termine il tutto.
Tecnicamente è realizzato decisamente male, numerosi bug ci costringeranno a utilizzare lo skip negli enigmi solo per poter proseguire cosa che fa veramente inviperire, sopratutto quando sapevamo come risolvere l'enigma della situazione.
Le animazioni 3D stile fine anni 90 poi sono la ciliegina sulla torta.

Unica nota positiva è la traduzione, che pur piena zeppa di errori grammaticali almeno traduce correttamente i nomi degli oggetti da cercare, evitandoci di cercare una bussola chiamandola "compasso".

Anche se il prezzo pieno non è altissimi, circa 8€, lo sconsiglio fortemente data la sua breve durata e la sua grezza realizzazione, ci sono fortunatamente titoli dello stesso sviluppatore che per lo stesso prezzo, o anche meno, riescono almeno a superare la sufficienza qualitativa che questo titolo non ha.

Pro:
-Traduzione degli oggetti da cercare, finalmente, in italiano corretto

Contro:
-Pieno di bug
-Stile imbarazzate
-Troppo semplice

review:
This #3 is the final part of the series but maybe it is better to say this is 2nd part of the #2. The mystery was solved in the previous episode but there is something more behind it. As for me it is nice and clever sequel. I believe this game is the best part of the series but it is not so improved when compared with #2. There are 2 years between their release dates. Generally I have a feeling that this series had maybe lower budget or something like that. Some parts of HOG mechanics are artificaly enlarged. You are sent to a different place to bring some item. Yes, it is typical in HOG but it is so explicit here. HOS are made well, items are bigger and rather easy to find. Minigames are sometimes strange especially the "repeat the sequence" game. You have to guess what to do. But generally quite good.
My recomendation is YES. You do not feel that it is older so intensively. The story is quite good but you can notice that there is some artificial extension. Generally this game is on higher level when compared to the other games of this age.

review:
Это было лучше, чем Time Mysteries 2, и оно прилично обернуло сюжетную линию от предыдущих 2 игр, хотя есть пара пробелов в сюжете, которые мне бы хотелось заполнить в первой игре. Сцены HO были с небольшим количеством трудностей, и они действительно повторялись, но, к счастью, не так много, как большинство игр, с которыми я сталкивался. Здесь раза 2 и обычно не больше. На этот раз головоломок было больше, чем было в TM2, и теперь они почти равны по количеству сценам HO. Кроме того, сложность головоломки хороша, и некоторые могут задержать вас на несколько минут. Озвучка чувствуется немного лучше, чем в других играх, но ненамного. И хоть саундтрек повторился с TM2, я не возражал, но он может раздражать вас, если вам мешают подобные вещи. Отступление также было уменьшено с хорошим запасом, но, как и у других HOG, откат еще присутствует. Я также действительно наслаждался пейзажем и художественными работами.

Достижения легко получить и требуют только одного прохождения.

В целом лучше, чем TM2 и хорошая игра, поэтому я рекомендую её, если вы хотите закончить сюжетную линию и провести некоторое время.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096304149', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 240, 'last_played': 1544692009}
review:
This was better than Time Mysteries 2, and it wrapped up the storyline from the previous 2 games decently, though there are a couple of plot holes that I would have liked filled from the first game. The HO scenes were just the right amount of difficult and they did repeat, but thankfully not too much like most games I've encountered. Here it's 2 and usually no more. There were more puzzles this time than there were in TM2 and are now almost equal in amount to the HO scenes. Also, the puzzle difficulty is nice and some may pause you for a few minutes. Voice acting felt a little better than other games, but not by much. And even though the soundtrack repeated from TM2, I didn't mind, but it may annoy you if that type of stuff bothers you. Backtracking was also reduced by a good margin, but just like other HOG's there is still backtracking present. I also really enjoyed the scenery and artwork. 

Achievements are easy to get and only require one playthrough.

Overall better than TM2 and a good game, so I recommend it if you want to finish the storyline and pass some time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198285597232', 'num_games_owned': 1167, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 231, 'last_played': 1539624319}
review:
[h1] TL;DR 6/10 Standard Artifex Mundi quality with some minor annoyances but some cool additions to the standard [/h1]

[b] Pros: [/b]
+ lovely environments
+ fairly diverse settings
+ okay puzzles
+ cool 'time traveling' mechanic

[b] Cons: [/b]
+ HO scenes had duplicate items (explained below)
+ 'hint' button essentially not functioning in 'expert' mode
+ fair amount of back tracking


This is a standard quality game for Artifex Mundi, so if you like their games, you'll enjoy this one too!

I found the time traveling mechanic which is typically just a map a pretty cool addition. It added another layer to the gameplay that I thought was fun and refreshing. The hint feature, however, was worthless when playing on 'expert' mode. It simply redirects you to your time travelling device and the compass, which when clicked reminds you to look for places on your time travelling device that have exclamation points. There are no exclamation points in expert mode. The only time it would help, is if you happened to be in a room where an action was availble already.

My other problem with this game, is the duplicate items present in some of the HO scenes.  Two in particular were frustrating for me; 1. You are looking for a 'feather', there were three feathers present on the screen. 2. 'Pistol' there were two pistols on that screen. Probably just a minor complaint, but it can be frustrating to know you found the right item, just not the right one to cross it off the list.

All-in-all it's your run of the mill Artifex Mundi game. I'd recommend it to any fans of the genre, but would maybe suggest newcomers look to another for their first hidden object puzzle adventure.

Happy gaming!

review:
This took me about 4.5 hours to complete. Good graphics and HOS, okay story-line, easy puzzles, good travelling map, and a decent and short bonus chapter. The "music" was a dreadful loop, and I kept it on low. Voice acting was not great, nor were the animated scenes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098765263', 'num_games_owned': 819, 'num_reviews': 246, 'playtime_forever': 194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 194, 'last_played': 1525673820}
review:
Time Mysteries 3: The Final Enigma – это заключительная часть игры в трилогии жанра «поиска предметов». Мы снова играем за Эстер Эмброуз, которая вновь отправляется в путешествие во времени к потомкам волшебника Мерлина, чтобы спасти всё человечество от могучего врага.
Необходимо отметить, что над игрой очень хорошо поработали. Сцены поиска предметов стали более чёткими, ролики красивее. Интересный сюжет и неплохое музыкальное сопровождение. В игре мне понравилось удобное перемещение по карте, с отмеченными точками действия. Русский язык (субтитры) в игре находится на отличном уровне. После полного прохождения игры открывается бонусный уровень, раскрывающий часть сюжета. Имеются дополнительные материалы – энциклопедия персонажей, обои. Все достижения можно выбить за один раз, если не пользоваться подсказками. А вот в бонусном уровне подсказки можно использовать, они на достижение не повлияют.
В целом игру можно отнести к «середнячкам» этого жанра. Игра интересная и не напрягает.
Оценка 8/10

review:
Definitivamente o melhor da trilogia, mas isso não muda o fato de que Time Mysteries é a pior franquia da Artiflex. 
A ordem cronologica da franquia é 2, 3, 1 e Time Mysteries 3 é uma continuação direta do 2, sendo desvendado os mistérios envolvendo a esposa do Merlin (Time Mysteries 2) e que isso está ligado ao viajante do futuro (Time Mysteries 1), porém criar roteiros envolvendo viagens no tempo é complicado e existem alguns paradoxos temporais na trilogia.
A grande questão sobre a franquia é que a história é muito forçada no primeiro, quase inexistente no segundo e o terceiro tenta enroscar os dois e salvar a pátria, mas acaba sendo fraco e é justamente a história que acaba diferenciando cada jogo de Objeto Oculto porque todo o restante é relativamente parecido, portanto no final das contas o único jogo decente da trilogia é o Time Mysteries 3: The Final Enigma, mas comparado aos demais jogos da Artilfex, ele é apenas mediano.

review:
[h1]Хорошая игра в жанре скрытых предметов.[/h1]

Последняя игра в трилогии. Сюжет является прямым продолжение предыдущей части. Мы снова играем за Эстер, наследницу семейства Эмброуз, путешественников во времени и потомков волшебника Мерлина. История стала глобальней – мы теперь спасаем весь мир. К сожалению, в сюжете есть конкретные ляпы, например нам так и не объясняют мотивы главного антагониста. Что-то становиться понятно после прочтения энциклопедии в конце игры, но это как-то не то. Да и вообще в игре наблюдаются проблемы с логикой. В самом начале игры нам надо проникнуть в дом, вход в который защищен магическим барьером. Так мы попадаем в дом через окошко в подвале. Так зачем было городить горожу с непробиваемым щитом, который можно просто обойти?

К игровому процессу тоже есть одна претензия – в нем много от моего самого нелюбимого режима игры «найди экзотический ключ, чтобы открыть экзотический замок, чтобы найти новый экзотический ключ. Повторить»

А вот картинка очень даже приличная. Разные времена в разной палитре, хорошая детализация и крупные объекты в режиме поиска. Смотреть приятно. Музыка не напрягает и ладно.

Игру скорее рекомендую. Она в меру интересная и не надоедает.

review:
I bought this game because i had just finished an Artifex Mundi trilogy and wanted more. It was also on sale, so I thought why not. But I hadn't played the other two games before this one so I was hesitant. 
I think this is an okay HOG, but it is very easy on the regular mode. The shines that show you which way to go next or what to press show up very quickly, so I didn't have to use my mind at times. 
Also, I would say maybe play the other games first if you wanna get into the story. There is a brief intro into whats happening, but other than that I didn't know who my character was and why I was doing this stuff. So, I didn't get pulled into the story, compared to when I did play through a complete HOG trilogy (Enigmatis).

With that said, I didn't hate the game. I would recommend it if you are looking for a random HOG to kill some time. If you wanna get into the story while doing that, I would recommend the Enigmatis trilogy from this developer instead. With Time Mysteries 3, once I got most of the achievements, I was able to click randomly through the hidden object puzzles, rather than take a good look. The Enigmatis trilogy has a few harder achievements to get, which you do have to take your time and look closely at each screen to get.
Because of that, I was able to play through all of TM3 including the extra story, in about 3 hours, while each Enigmatis game took about 5-6 hours. So, if you want this game, I would not recommend paying full price for half the gameplay of Artifex Mundi's other games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995982646', 'num_games_owned': 4614, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 464, 'last_played': 1519325128}
review:
Time Mysteries 3 kicks off to a good beginning from the moment you hit the start button. Cut scenes and puzzles alternate well with a good flow between them. First locations have good scenery, with colorfull, smooth, ambient hue's, immediatly setting the atmosphere for the rest of the game.
 
Most of the puzzles encountered, have an intuitive feel to them, whilst not being too easy and/or straightforward, the're rather fun and challenging. Cannot recall a single puzzle that i disliked during my playthrough. The hidden object scenes themselves are a bit easier than in TM2, which can be seen as a pluspoint, since the ones in TM2 were simply too hard. Points with interactions and other spots of interest, embedded in the locations scenery, are harder to locate, however. More than once, i found myself lowering the difficulty setting from expert to regular, to locate those.

All or, at least, most of the flaws made in TM1 and TM2 are resolved in TM3. Everything is done a bit better and feels more balanced. Making this version the best of the trilogy. (As it should be, since the learning curve for new developer studio Artifex Mundi is at it's steepest during the creation of one of their first projects, the Time Mystery trilogy). For instance: the animation shown when using the time device, has improved animations and a shorter duration.

All achievements can be unlocked in one playthrough, in case you don't skip any of the hidden object scenes by playing the mini games, that substitute them, instead. The bonus chapter, which is rather fast paced, also has to be completed in order to unlock the last two achievements.

Recommended for hidden object games lovers, people who played the first two games and achievement hunters. A worthy end to the trilogy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004233477', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1518675861}
review:
I've played Time Mysteries 1-3 in the past week. What a disappointment. I do not recommend any of these games.

I love Artifex Mundi games. My favorite series by them is probably Nightmares From The Deep. However, the Time Mysteries games were all duds. They are all also short. I have finished each game, including bonus chapters. TM1 is 2 hours long. TM2 is 3 hours long. TM3 is 2 hours long. It's much shorter than other Artifex Mundi games. Maybe the games were all kept to 2-3 hours because AM cared about pacing.

The Time Mysteries series follows 2 girls in the Ambrose family of timetravelers: Vivien (1) and Esther (2+3). The three games, played in order, form one cohesive story. Games 2+3 are basically one sequel, in two parts, to Game 1 (Game 2 literally ends with the words "to be continued"). Although the games technically standalone, you need to have played Time Mysteries 1+2 to understand the story in Time Mysteries 3.

Time Mysteries 3 revisits some places from earlier games, but, I didn't personally have an issue with that, except for when it came to the bonus story in Time Mysteries 3.

As HOPA games, they're just not as fun as the other AM games. The hidden object puzzles are too repetitive and either way too easy or way too hard, depending on the game in the series. For Time Mysteries 3, the puzzles were all way too easy. I never had an issue solving a puzzle in under a few minutes.

As time travel games, 1-2 are fine, but 3 is not great. While the story's stakes were high on a meta level, solving puzzles across time to earn an awl or a chainsaw or a candle felt underwhelming. In Time Mysteries 3, you're tasked with finding at least 3 sets of items, and you need a minimum of 3 items to complete each set. The items felt like filler items included to avoid having to come up with other puzzles and felt like busywork, which made the story feel like it was plodding along.

Objects I want to be looking for in a time travel game: cool stuff from the past or future that has relevance in the plot later.

Objects I don't want to be searching for in a time travel game: piano keys to solve a boring piano puzzle to get a box of matches or something.

A big issue was that time travel was not as huge of an element in this game as travel across "space". The "Time Changes" from Time Mysteries 2 (doing things in Area A at Time X will affect things in Area A at Time Y, etc.) appeared, but minimally, in Time Mysteries 3, and really don't appear at all in Time Mysteries 1 (which basically has some short themed zones to visit and never revisit). There were very few puzzles that affected things in a given area at a later point of the timeline. 

It mostly seemed to be a game about gathering the right items in different time periods, in order to collect more items.

Frankly, the game was about a girl making a medicine for her relative, and then, giving the relative a prism and a necklace, before stopping the villain before he became a villain at all (which makes 0 sense to do given they already stopped him)(so do one or the other). That's really it, but it stretches out of 2-3 hours of what are the HOPA equivalent of fetch quests.

The puzzles weren't challenging and no instructions were given on how to complete puzzles (a standard feature in most AM and HOPA games). This was fine for me, as someone who has played the types of puzzles that showed up int his game in other AM and HOPA games, but for someone new to the genre, or someone who just wants or prefers instructions, this is frustrating. It never hindered my ability to play the game, but it was a slight nuisance.

Finally, in Time Mysteries 3, the bonus story recycles hidden object puzzles from previous games as well as from Time Mysteries 3. The list of items to find in the puzzle doesn't change, which is especially frustrating. 

[b]HOPA fan specific notes:[/b]

Game does contain a really sick/physically hurt looking kid, as well as a dead body (skeleton of the kid in one timeline), as well as a dead prisoner, so if that's not something you are comfortable with, now you know.

The games do not have any collectibles.

The art is okay. Not AM's best, not AM's worst.

The soundtrack seems recycled from TM2. I was hoping for new songs. I could be wrong about this.

I know TM3 has a minigame you can play to skip the HOPA, but I'm not sure what it is, as I never played it.

Hidden object puzzles do repeat, some with identical lists of things to find (TM3's bonus story does this with puzzles from TM3 and TM2).

The bonus stories are short.

[b]Technical issues (Mac):[/b]

Character animations were worse than most of this game's contemporaries in the Artifex Mundi portfolio.

In Time Mysteries 3, the various scenes in the Moscow area had issues with loading, and in one case, outright skipped a cutscene, which made the rest of the game confusing. 

Every single game also showed a crash screen (I'm on Mac) upon exiting the game, even though nothing bad happened (I could load the game up and it worked fine). Luckily, the crash screen never appeared during normal play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046407276', 'num_games_owned': 6090, 'num_reviews': 233, 'playtime_forever': 399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1508188779}
review:
[h1]Final of a weak line...[/h1]

Of the Time Mysteries Series this game is the last, and also the best. Most issues which were frequent on the first two parts were evened out. And even the story got a bit more of an explanation, albeit a more or less weak one. The game in general is the best of the series, offering very accessible HOGs, easy to medium puzzles and some nice cutscenes. The Look and feel of the game is more pretty than the other two parts.

[table]

[tr][th]Category[/th][th]Score[/th][th]Notes[/th][/tr]
[tr][td]Graphics[/td][td]8[/td][td]For a game of this Genre the graphics are good.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Sound[/td][td]8[/td][td]The Soundtrack is good, the voiceacting albeit not bad, a bit off the track.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Hidden Objects[/td][td]8[/td][td]The HOGs are well made, the items actually are well to find if you look for them.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Puzzles[/td][td]7[/td][td]Easy to Intermediate, not too hard to puzzle out, although I read people complain, that there are hard puzzles.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Playability[/td][td]7[/td][td]Okay. It's a HOG, and this one isn't too sloppy with the mouse aim. Replayability = Zilch![/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Value[/td][td]6[/td][td]Given the quality and the length this game is borderline in Value for the Money, since no replayability and around 3 to 6 hours of playtime... it's a bit high.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Bonus[/td][td]5[/td][td]The Bonus was hard to swallow, because it causes a bit of confusion storywise.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Overall[/td][th]7[/th][td]*[/td][/tr]
[/table]

[h1]Recommended[/h1]

Because this is the best part of the storyline, only the Bonus was a bit confusing and moved the player into a wrong direction - red herring. The story as a whole still isn't so fluid as with some other storylines, and it's one of the weaker Artifex Mundi titles around. Still a worthwhile game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036328736', 'num_games_owned': 3959, 'num_reviews': 727, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1502117396}
review:
Esther est perturbée par d'intrigants rêves concernant Viviane croisée dans le second épisode. Son oncle l'invite alors à le rejoindre. Elle va devoir à nouveau multiplier les voyages dans le temps pour sauver le monde promis à la destructions totale dans le futur.

Dans cet épisode final à la trilogie, on retrouve les mêmes déplacements à travers le temps que dans le précédent opus et le principe d'agir dans le passé pour modifier le futur. On explore toujours les différents lieux pour récolter des objets utiles et on en récupére d'autres dans des SOC.


Ce titre est de la même qualité que le second épisode et apporte un point final à l'histoire. Les mini-jeux sont faciles et les énigmes évidentes à partir du moment où on déniche le bon objet.
L'épisode bonus permet de jouer le voyageur du futur croisé dans les épisodes 2 et 3. On retourne dans les lieux de ces deux épisodes mais surtout on a droit à quelques-unes des mêmes SOC!


Bref, ce jeu fait partie des bons jeux dans le genre et même si le premier épisode est moins bon, prendre la trilogie dans un pack en soldes est une bonne idée.

review:
Time Mysteries 3 est un jeu d'Objets Cachés classique (HOG, Hidden Object Game) qui prend place dans une trilogie avec comme thème le voyage dans le temps. Plusieurs références et lieux font des rappels aux précédents opus, mais celui-ci peut être parfaitement joué sans les autres. 

En mode Expert, comptez 4 bonnes heures pour le terminer avec le chapitre Bonus (faisant un peu trop "recyclage" parfois même si l'idée est bonne). Bénéficiant des mêmes atouts (moins linéaire, animations...) que le N°2, il m'a semblé plus facile que le précédent mais également moins long (moins de HOG, des mini-jeux même simplistes parfois). Ainsi comme le précédent certaines scènes d'Objets Cachés sont "dynamiques" (il faut agir pour obtenir l'objet convoité) et vous trouverez également de petites animations qui donnent un tout petit peu de vie à l'ensemble. 

Prendre les 3 jeux en pack et en promotion.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982180153', 'num_games_owned': 2960, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1490424929}
review:
Ho giocato ai precedenti capitoli della serie ma non ricordo molto. A dirla tutta, sebbene segua sempre con decente attenzione le storie degli HOG, raramente mi restano impresse poiché piuttosto banali.
Quindi non riuscirò a fare una comparazione coi precedenti capitoli, ma da quello che ricordo, mi avevano lasciato una buona impressione.

Il gioco è un classico HOG della Artifex Mundi ma con l'interessante novità di poter viaggiare nel tempo per trovare oggetti o luoghi in un diverso stato, rendendo possibili interazioni che altrimenti non lo sarebbero. Un'altra premessa è che, questo fattore viaggio nel tempo, possa farvi cambiare il futuro, rettificando errori commessi dal cattivone di turno.
In realtà, l'effettiva modificazione degli eventi, in questo capitolo accade solo 2 volte (che io mi ricordi), rendendo l'intero sistema solo una scusa per la creazione di ambientazioni con diverso stile.

E non è nemmeno l'unico punto scadente del gioco. 
La storia, per quanto non pretenda certo roba da Oscar, è piuttosto noiosa e prevedibile, e spesso mi sono trovato a saltare dialoghi o a fare altro mentre venivano mostrati.
Anche gli oggetti necessari per superare gli ostacoli, spesso, non c'entrano molto, rendendo questa caccia un processo con una logica contorta e insensata (per fortuna c'è la mappa con spostamenti rapidi). Sembra che gli "enigmi" siano stati messi puramente a caso, senza pensarci troppo, giusto per riempire il gioco.

Ma quello che non mi sarei mai aspettato da Artifex Mundi è di fallire nelle scene HO: spesso i nomi degli oggetti da trovare sono errati (io gioco in inglese, di solito, per migliorarmi ed evitare traduzione da google translate in italiano), ed ancora più spesso ci sono oggetti doppi o tripli nella scena, facendovi credere che il gioco abbia dei bug che non gli faccia rilevare i vostri click. Anche il sonar non è di aiuto, visto che la sagoma dell'oggetto spesso non dice nulla, quando avete problemi a trovarlo.

Non parliamo poi dell'avventura extra. Talmente riciclata e insensata che ho premuto spesso "skip" (salta) in alcuni mini giochi per farla finita il prima possibile.

In definitiva un gioco breve, anche se nella media per questo genere, ma piuttosto deludente per gli standard di questa azienda, fatto con poca logica e poca passione.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971047607', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 184, 'last_played': 1479938029}
review:
Time Mysteries 3: The Final Enigma is the final chapter in the Time Mysteries series and does a good job at wrapping up all three stories and connecting them while also tying up loose ends.

The game itself is nothing special and is a little dated, as are the previous two games, but if you like the Hidden Object genre, then all three games will probably satisfy you. No bugs, reasonable voice acting, plenty of puzzles, and lots of HO scenes.

Time Mysteries 3 also has a bonus chapter, as had Time Mysteries 2, but while the bonus material in TM2 was mostly original, the bonus chapter in TM3 is mainly re-used HO scenes (with the same objects) from TM2 and TM3 which was a little disappointing.

Overall, the trilogy is a decent, if not spectacular, journey through time with the Ambrose family that is perhaps on the easy side for experienced HO players, but still worth making.

Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a Point and click hidden object game.



[h1]Interface/Menu/Settings[/h1]

You can have different profile slots.
There is a music volume slidebar.
There is a sound volume slidebar.
There is normal and expert mode.


[h1]About the game.[/h1]

 You are trying to find out the mystery of your own family and you will enter a mansion by doing so.   You are able to play a different minigame when you are doing the hidden object. This minigame is 10 faster and easier to complete then doing the hidden object. Each time you have filled up the bar, you get a question mark and if you pop that. You will cross off 1 random hidden object. It's sort of ruining the purpose of the hidden object.

Alternative way to beat hidden objects.
There is a hint system.
There is voice over and it sounds a bit "stale" (without an expression).
The subtitles are voiced over.
Has puzzles.
Lot of collectables.
Weak guide lines.
There is video animation/cutscene.
There is only a map available if you have unlocked the time machine thing.
Sometimes during the hidden object scene. The objects are BEHIND every decoration. Which makes it impossible to see with the bare eyes.

[h1]Other things.[/h1]

It's an okay game but the "toggle minigame" at hidden objects really ruins the game. So i can;t give it a high number.

-------------------

I Give this game a 6/10

review:
In the final Time Mystery series u will be playing as Esther again. More time traveling with Esther:) This time u will have to find the reason as to why Viviana turned evil. Yup she returns again in the final Time Mystery series.

The characters are nice. It was really nice ti find out more about what happend to Viviana. The music was I think all the same like the second game. Some places u visit will remix that music u will be hearing a lot. I don't mind the music being the same as I loved the music from the second game:) The BG was very nice. The cutscenes not the stongest. The VA was ok.

The final Time Mystery game wraps up both the first and second story. In my opinion I enjoyed the second one a lot. 
I think I enjoyed the second one more because it was the longest of the three to play which means more content.

Esther was really cool with all the good that she did in the second and third game:) 

U do visit a place u are very familiar with if played the first game. I tell u with the improved graphics that familiar place looked really beautiful.

As the second game u do have a bonus story that was interesting to play. Again like the second game after u finish the game u get an encyclopedia which is very helpful to read.

Overall I had a lot of fun playing the Time Mystery series. If the series was polished a bit better I bet the Time Mystery series would of been getting more postive reviews than mixed reviews.

[h1]- Review below ----------------------------------------------------------------------[/h1]

Time Mysteries 3: The Final Enigma is a sequel of Time Mysteries 2: The Ancient Spectres.
You play as Ester Ambrose to save the world of an evil cataclysm that a hooded face wants to happen. She will need to time travel in order to be able to save the world and prevent the cataclysm to occur. And then begin a new journey for her.

As every Artifex Mundi game you can move freely in different area and need to solve some puzzles and find all objects in hidden objects scenes. The game has (different difficulties?) and a guest feature: every one of the family can play an independent save and resume the game where they left it. When you first play the game you’ll have a notebook where you have all your objectives as well as all your notes. You’ll also have a time travel device showing a map that allow you to fast-travel. Adding to that you’ll have a hint button that will help you in many ways but be warned that you may not use it in any puzzle or hidden object scene (HOS)or investigation scene (IS). Hints can be used to know where you need to go, where is the next interaction or to show an object or clue in an HOS or IS or to skip a puzzle. To conclude this part, you’ll also have an inventory to store useful items through your journey.

Puzzles are good and different. Hidden objects scenes (HOS) have only the classical one (as far as I remember): find objects hidden with the help of their name. Orange names mean that you need to interact directly with the scene or use an item in the scene.

One of the very good thing of this game is that there are 2 unique features you won’t find in any other Artifex Mundi game (except Time Mysteries):
•	You’ll be able to freely move through time (and space) with your time travel device.
•	You’re able to play a unique mini-game instead of the HOS. (I don’t really suggest it if you’re going for achievements though.)

To do so (to time travel) you’ll first need to find it (?) and to retrieve every token to be able to travel to specific dates.

And for the mini-game, as far as I recall I think that’s a matching game: you need to click on a chain of three or more adjacent balls to remove them. (The aim is to let some kind of token to fall out of the screen or to remove adjacent balls?) Each time you remove a token you remove also an item in the hidden objects list.

(*) : 
In addition to no skip or use any hint while playing every puzzles and Hidden objects scenes, there are a few more missable achievements. Two of them requires you to complete a puzzle and a hidden objects scene under one minute. And 2 other hidden objects achievements ask you to find 3 objects within 3 seconds or to finish a scene with less than 4 misclicks. 

Finally if you missed anything while finishing your first playthrough, you’ll need to play the game again. I guess but I’m not sure that you need to play on the same profile to get the “One of a kind” achievement.

review:
Better than the first two.

Hidden objects were not cheaply placed for the most part, as in placing objects that blended together.  I did not need to pixel hunt a few inches from my screen.  Hidden object scenes were also of good enough quality and resolution that I did not stress out when doing them.  There were also not a lot of clutter and objects were not too small.

Graphics are stretched, even though cutscenes were in widescreen.  That can't be helped though; it is the nature of the genre.

There were a minor aesthetic/visual glitch and a major gamebreaking bug though.  The major bug involved using objects on environments.  When I used the objects, my cursor disappeared and I couldn't close the pop-up interaction scene.  I had to exit to the main menu and then go back into the game.  Luckily, the game saves the exact location and the activities you have done.

The story is a good wrap-up of the first two games.  It connected the first two games of the series, whereas the second game had a new story, completely disconnected from the first.  Story was still cheesy though.

There is fast travel and helpful hints on what to do next.  Those helped cut down the amount of time wasted going back and forth; nobody wants to do that.

Overall, the game was decent to below decent.  Hidden object scenes were not frustrating.  This game is fine for HOG fans, but passable for everybody else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026806776', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 302, 'playtime_forever': 161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 161, 'last_played': 1468083528}
review:
[i]Time Mysteries 3[/i] wraps up [url=store.steampowered.com/search/?publisher=Artifex%20Mundi]Artifex Mundi's[/url] saga of magic and time-travel, bringing the traditional melodrama to a by-the-numbers conclusion where where everyone, [b]everyone[/b] lives happily ever after.  

The first game in this series was a disaster.  The second was passable but had a few notable flaws.  The third time is evidently the charm.  This final outing for the series still didn't seem quite as good as some of AM's other offerings, but the blatant weaknesses of the previous two are not to be seen here.  It's a solid HOG with nothing much to complain about.

Regrettably for those who enjoy a challenge, as QA stepped up in this game, difficulty took a step down.  But Artifex Mundi fans should already be familiar with AM's emphasis on aesthetics and storytelling over challenge.  Playing on Expert typically helps in an AM game, but I don't recommend it in the later two [i]Time Mysteries[/i] games because of the time-travel mechanic -- without the helpful "something to do" icons on the Portable Time Device, you'd be stuck rewandering every time era over and over to find where HO scenes have become reactivated.

In the final analysis, this is a decent HOG on its own, though having played the other two first does give it more context, and it's definitely the best of the trilogy.  The trilogy as a whole, however, is decidedly sub-par for this publisher.  If you haven't yet played much of Artifex Mundi's catalogue, you'd do better to start elsewhere.

review:
Que dire de ce jeu, Time Mysteries 3 fait, à mon sens, parti de ces Point & Click tout ce qu'il y a de plus moyen. 

Avant d'en dire plus, je me dois de préciser que je n'ai pas joué aux deux précédents volets de la trilogie, oui honte à moi parce que du coup je ne pourrais pas très bien vous parler de l'histoire. Cependant malgré mon ignorance cela n'a pas empéché l'histoite d'être prenante et c'est plutôt un bon point pour le jeu ! Mais bon j'imagine qu'il vaut mieux commencer par le 1 quand même...^^

Revenons à nos moutons, une durée de vie de 3h en ayant débloqué les 11 achievements, ça reste court ! Et plus que court je dirais que c'est un jeu facile, aucune énigme ne pose vraiment problème, il en va de même pour les HOS.

L'environnement du jeu est un plus par contre, l'univers est sympa, visuellement il n'y a rien à reprocher à ce jeu, les petites scènes par ci par là ne gachent rien, bon on pourra toujours trouver mieux ailleurs mais on va pas commencer à chipoter.

Le jeu se positionne donc dans la moyenne des point & click et je le recommande si vous aimez le genre, je trouve qu'il ne vaut pas les 8 € demandés mais n'hésitez pas si vous le trouvez en solde ! C'est un jeu très correct et plaisant pour passer une soirée ou une après-midi... ou ce que vous voulez en fait.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092527319', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1462371245}
review:
Un dernier volet très prenant, sans doute mon préféré de la trilogie. On veut connaitre l'issue de l'histoire, les époques sont mélangés (donc chacun y trouve son compte), les interactions avec les personnages sont plus nombreuses et les énigmes (surtout dans l'épisode bonus) sont moins simplistes bien que déjà vues.

Les + :
- L'histoire
- Les interactions avec les personnages plus nombreuses
- L'univers
- les sons ambiants qui ont été travaillés

Les - :
- Quelques énigmes toujours un peu simplistes
- Le rappel au premier épisode (même si j'ai aimé, certains trouveront que Artifex Mundi n'a fait que "copier" sur le premier volet à certains moments du jeu)

Il reste néanmoins le meilleur volet de la trilogie à mon sens (j'ai laissé tourné le jeu, mais sa durée de vie doit se résumer à 6h environ) et je le recommande pour les amateurs de SOC, vous ne serez pas déçus (mais préférez faire la trilogie depuis le début, c'est plus sympathique) ;)

[h1]Описание:[/h1]
Игра представленная в жанре - "Я ищу", в которой нам предстоит вновь предстать в роли юной девушки, уже пережившей большое приключение во второй части игры (которая закончилась открытой концовкой). В этот раз нам вновь предстоит отправиться в путешествие по времени чтобы окончательно разгадать тайну предков и завершить историю.

[h1]Плюсы:[/h1]
¥ Удобное перемещение по карте с помеченными точками действия. В ручную перемещаться почти не придется.
¥ Русский язык (субтитры).
¥ В игре присутствуют мини игры (интересные и не очень).
¥ В игру включена дополнительная глава раскрывающая часть сюжета.
¥ Есть прямые отсылки к прошлым частям игры (особенно приятно, что затронули первую часть).
¥ В сравнении с прошлыми частями, игра наполнена анимированными видео вставками, которые радуют глаз.
¥ На этот раз сцен с поиском предмета меньше и они более-менее интересны.

[h1]Минусы:[/h1]
¥ Сюжетная часть все таки оставляет желать лучшего.

[h1]Достижения:[/h1]
Все достижения можно получить за одно полное прохождение игры. Главное не пользоваться подсказками и не пропускать мини-игры. Сложность выбирайте - гость, вам будет намного проще играть, а на достижения сложность не влияет. После прохождения основной части и играя в дополнительный эпизод, где можно вовсю начинать пользоваться подсказками и пропусками мини-игр.

[h1]Итог:[/h1]
Достойное завершение довольно слабой трилогии. Полностью законченная сюжетная часть. Довольно продолжительная и интересная дополнительная глава. Рекомендую исключительно если вы столкнулись с прошлыми частями игры, чтобы узнать, чем все закончилось. Можно начинать играть и с этой части, т.к. нам преподносят сюжет прошлых частей и не будет так, что ничего не понятно. Собственно говоря палец подниму вверх.

[h1]Оценка: 5/10[/h1]

[h1]Послесловие:[/h1]
Если вам понравился этот обзор добро пожаловать в группу
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/uojer - тут вы сможете увидеть рекомендованные мною игры, другие обзоры, а также просто пообщаться в хорошей компании.

review:
結論言うと面白いです。

内容はファンタジー絡みの探偵物と言ったところでしょうか？
週末に軽く楽しむ、短編や中篇程度の小説のように楽しむことができます。

総当りクリックのアドベンチャー・ゲームに特有の同じ場所を行ったり来たりして時間を費やされる事も、
ヒント機能が非常に充実しているのでテンポを崩さず物語に集中できます。
次の行き先やアクション、パズルにもヒントは適用されるのでまずストレスが溜まるということもないでしょう。
パズルについては面倒ならスキップまでできてしまいます。

但し、2と3は続き物なので購入時は一緒に買った方が良いですよ。

review: "The Final Enigma" jest trzecią, ostatnią odsłoną serii Time Mysteries, jak dla mnie równie dobrą jak druga część, chociaż historia dodatkowa już tak nie porywa jak w poprzedniej części. "Ostatnia zagadka" to dokończenie, ciąg dalszy historii z drugiej części. Jest tu wyraźne nawiązanie do pierwszej części, jest nawet wspólny dla nich bohater z przyszłości, ale i tak największe zainteresowanie wzbudza pewnie historia Merlina i Viviany. Pod względem grafiki i animacji część trzecia nie różni się od poprzedniczki, historia jest nieco bardziej dramatyczna, ale zagadki są na równym poziomie, ani za łatwe, ani za trudne. Polecam :)

review: The third and final istallment in the Time Mysteries series is by far the best one. They upped everything, artwork, puzzles, sound and higher resolution on the hidden object parts. Set by itself this is good game, but the story builds heavily on the second one, which ended on a "to be continued" note. So the story by itself might not mean much of you haven't played the second one. But it is much more engaging than the first two of the series. What I like the most with this one still has to be the artwork, the cutscenes looks a little cheap but the artwork is really good and is at an Artifex Mundi level which I expect from them. Playing games like this it's so much more fun if it's nice to look at when you're scanning every location for useful objects or even hidden objects. By far the best Time Mysteries, but they still have series like; Nightmares from the Deep, Grim Legends and 9 Clues that are better, mostly in the story but also artwork. All and all, still a good game. 6.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198062674571', 'num_games_owned': 5359, 'num_reviews': 214, 'playtime_forever': 226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1458412227}
review:
Time Mysteries 3: The Final Enigma to trzecia odsłona cyklu przygodowych gier logicznych, stworzonych przez polskie studio Artifex Mundi. W grze wcielamy się w znaną z drugiej części serii Ester Ambrose. Po zniszczeniu kryształu będącego magicznym więzieniem czarownicy Vivianny mogłoby się wydawać, że niebezpieczeństwo zostało zażegnane. Okazuje się jednak, że to nie ona była tak naprawdę zagrożeniem, a nasza bohaterka ponownie musi wyruszyć w podróż przez czas i przestrzeń, aby zapobiec tragedii w przyszłości. Znajomość poprzednich odsłon serii nie jest niezbędna do zrozumienia Time Mysteries 3, aczkolwiek jest tu do nich kilka nawiązań.

The Final Enigma to, moim zdaniem, najlepsza część cyklu, głównie ze względu na fabułę, która jest ciekawsza i bardziej spójna niż w jej poprzedniczkach. Pod względem rozgrywki jednak gra nie prezentuje niczego nowego, więc jeżeli ktoś grał w Time Mysteries 2: The Ancient Spectres, to dobrze wie, czego się po tej części spodziewać. Standardowo mamy tu do czynienia z połączeniem przygodowej gry point'n'click z licznymi sekwencjami hidden object, urozmaiconym szeregiem minigier logicznych. Wszystkie te elementy rozgrywki prezentują się całkiem dobrze. Zagadki są przemyślane, dobrze wykorzystują motyw przemieszczania się w czasie, a ich rozwiązania są logiczne. Sekwencjom hidden object, polegającym na wyszukiwaniu na ekranie wskazanych przedmiotów też nie można niczego zarzucić. Żaden z obiektów nie sprawia wrażenia, jakby pochodził z innego obrazka, dzięki czemu sceny wyglądają jednolicie. Ponadto przedmioty są całkiem sprytnie poukrywane. Wymagają od gracza nie tylko spostrzegawczości, ale też odrobiny myślenia. Przykładowo zdarza się, że aby znaleźć jeden z przedmiotów, musimy najpierw otworzyć pojemnik, w którym on się znajduje albo włączyć ekran, na którym jest wyświetlany. Nie jest tajemnicą, że Time Mysteries 3: The Final Enigma jest grą casualową, mającą zapewnić przyjemną i raczej prostą rozgrywkę. Pomagają w tym liczne, opcjonalne ułatwienia. Jeśli graczowi nie odpowiadają sekwencje hidden object, może zamiast nich przejść prostą grę logiczną. Poza tym prawie w każdej chwili może on skorzystać z podpowiedzi lub nawet pominąć daną łamigłówkę. Tytuł może się poszczycić ładną, ręcznie rysowaną grafiką oraz przyjemną dla ucha ścieżką dźwiękową.

Choć uważam Ostatnią Zagadkę za najlepszą część serii, to nie wszystko mi się w niej podobało. Przede wszystkim gra jest krótka, krótsza od Time Mysteries 2. Składa się ona z dwóch kampanii, które można ukończyć nawet w trzy godziny. Trochę mało. A jak już o tym mowa, to gra składa się z części głównej oraz pomniejszej dodatkowej opowieści. I ta druga niestety zawodzi. Z jednej strony pozwala ona spojrzeć na przedstawione w grze wydarzenia z perspektywy innego bohatera, ale oprócz tego nie oferuje prawie nic. Większość zagadek i sekwencji hidden object to to samo, co widzieliśmy w pierwszej kampanii oraz Time Mysteries 2. Często są one po prostu żywcem z nich skopiowane. Główna część produkcji też ma kilka wad i niedoskonałości. Fabuła momentami sprawia wrażenie, jakby była za bardzo uproszczona, animacje są sztywne. W polskiej lokalizacji znalazło się kilka literówek, a przy jednej lokacji odniosłem wrażenie, jakby ktoś przez pomyłkę narysował ją w złym rozmiarze i później dość nieumiejętnie próbował zamaskować ten błąd. Są to w sumie szczegóły, ale powinno ich nie być w ogóle.

Podsumowując, Time Mysteries 3: The Final Enigma to według mnie najlepsza część cyklu, ale na pewno nie zalicza się ona do najlepszych produkcji studia Artifex Mundi. Produkcja boryka się z tymi samymi, co prawda nielicznymi, problemami, co jej poprzedniczki i do tego jest trochę za krótka. Jednak, co ważniejsze, oferuje tą samą przyjemną rozgrywkę. Jeśli więc komuś spodobały się dwie poprzednie odsłony Time Mysteries, to The Final Enigma również powinno mu się spodobać.
